articles.headline: Regulators Penalize Microsoft in Europe
articles.snippet: The European Commission fined Microsoft $357 million for failing to comply with a 2004 antitrust order.
articles.abstract: The European Commission fined Microsoft $357 million for failing to comply with a 2004 antitrust order.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS, July 12 — The European Commission fined Microsoft $357 million on Wednesday for failing to comply with an antitrust order, even as the company faces more battles with European regulators over its next big product.
articles.byline: By Paul Meller and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: 2 Cameras That Break Some Rules
articles.snippet: Two longstanding rules have just come tumbling down in the world of inexpensive digital S.L.R. (single-lens reflex) cameras.
articles.abstract: Two longstanding rules have just come tumbling down in the world of inexpensive digital S.L.R. (single-lens reflex) cameras.
articles.lead_paragraph: SO much in technology changes so fast, it’s a great mental relief when you encounter an absolute rule that will never change. You know, like “Whatever you buy today will look overpriced and underpowered next year,” or “The next version of Windows will be bigger than the previous one.”

articles.headline: A Mission to Repeal Murphy’s Law
articles.snippet: Beset by misfortune in the United States, BP has installed a Mr. Fix-It in Robert A. Malone.
articles.abstract: Beset by misfortune in the United States, BP has installed a Mr. Fix-It in Robert A. Malone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, just days after he officially took on a new assignment to run BP’s business in the United States, Robert A. Malone took off for the Alaskan tundra to visit one of the hottest of the several hot spots in the global oil company’s increasingly troubled North American portfolio.

articles.headline: Some Leeway for the Small Shoplifter
articles.snippet: In a rare display of limited permissiveness, Wal-Mart is letting thieves off the hook in cases involving $25 or less.
articles.abstract: In a rare display of limited permissiveness, Wal-Mart is letting thieves off the hook in cases involving $25 or less.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart refuses to carry smutty magazines. It will not sell compact discs with obscene lyrics. And when it catches customers shoplifting  even a pair of socks or a pack of cigarettes  it prosecutes them.

articles.headline: Deal Is Seen for Creating Urban Films
articles.snippet: A potential joint venture would be a first step toward creating a major force in urban entertainment.
articles.abstract: A potential joint venture would be a first step toward creating a major force in urban entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, July 12  The Weinstein Company, the film studio started by the founders of Miramax, is near a deal to form a joint venture with Robert L. Johnson, founder of Black Entertainment Television, to create an urban entertainment company, according to people involved in the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Laura M. Holson

articles.headline: Paralyzed Man Uses Thoughts to Move a Cursor
articles.snippet: A paralyzed man with a small sensor implanted in his brain was able to control a computer, a television set and a robot using only his thoughts, scientists reported yesterday.     Those results offer hope that in the future, people with spinal cor...
articles.abstract: A paralyzed man with a small sensor implanted in his brain was able to control a computer, a television set and a robot using only his thoughts, scientists reported yesterday.     Those results offer hope that in the future, people with spinal cord injuries, Lou Gehrig's disease or other conditions that impair movement may be able to communicate or better control their world.
articles.lead_paragraph: A paralyzed man with a small sensor implanted in his brain was able to control a computer, a television set and a robot using only his thoughts, scientists reported yesterday.

articles.headline: Deal Is Seen for Creating Urban Films
articles.snippet: The Weinstein Company, the film studio started by the founders of Miramax, is near a deal to form a joint venture with Robert L. Johnson, founder of Black Entertainment Television, to create an urban entertainment company, according to people invo...
articles.abstract: The Weinstein Company, the film studio started by the founders of Miramax, is near a deal to form a joint venture with Robert L. Johnson, founder of Black Entertainment Television, to create an urban entertainment company, according to people involved in the negotiations.     The joint venture could be announced as early as Thursday, these people said, though they cautioned that the deal could be delayed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, July 12 - The Weinstein Company, the film studio started by the founders of Miramax, is near a deal to form a joint venture with Robert L. Johnson, founder of Black Entertainment Television, to create an urban entertainment company, according to people involved in the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Laura M. Holson

articles.headline: Some Leeway for the Small Shoplifter
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart refuses to carry smutty magazines. It will not sell compact discs with obscene lyrics. And when it catches customers shoplifting -- even a pair of socks or a pack of cigarettes -- it prosecutes them.      But now, in a rare display of lim...
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart refuses to carry smutty magazines. It will not sell compact discs with obscene lyrics. And when it catches customers shoplifting -- even a pair of socks or a pack of cigarettes -- it prosecutes them.      But now, in a rare display of limited permissiveness, Wal-Mart is letting thieves off the hook -- at least in cases involving $25 or less.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart refuses to carry smutty magazines. It will not sell compact discs with obscene lyrics. And when it catches customers shoplifting -- even a pair of socks or a pack of cigarettes -- it prosecutes them.

articles.headline: Israelis Enter Lebanon After Attacks
articles.snippet: The Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah surprised Israel with a bold daylight assault across the border on Wednesday, leading to fighting in which two Israeli soldiers were captured and at least eight killed, and elevating recent tensions into a se...
articles.abstract: The Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah surprised Israel with a bold daylight assault across the border on Wednesday, leading to fighting in which two Israeli soldiers were captured and at least eight killed, and elevating recent tensions into a serious two-front battle.     Israel, already waging a military operation in the Gaza Strip to free a soldier captured by Palestinian militants on June 25, immediately responded by sending armored forces into southern Lebanon for the first time in six years.
articles.byline: By Greg Myre and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Regulators Penalize Microsoft in Europe
articles.snippet: The European Commission fined Microsoft $357 million on Wednesday for failing to comply with an antitrust order, even as the company faces more battles with European regulators over its next big product.     The fine was meant to punish the compan...
articles.abstract: The European Commission fined Microsoft $357 million on Wednesday for failing to comply with an antitrust order, even as the company faces more battles with European regulators over its next big product.     The fine was meant to punish the company for not sharing technical information about its hugely profitable Windows operating system with competitors, as it was ordered to in a European antitrust ruling in 2004. It was the first time a company had been fined for not obeying a European antitrust order.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS, July 12 - The European Commission fined Microsoft $357 million on Wednesday for failing to comply with an antitrust order, even as the company faces more battles with European regulators over its next big product.
articles.byline: By Paul Meller and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: A Mission to Repeal Murphys Law
articles.snippet: Last week, just days after he officially took on a new assignment to run BP's business in the United States, Robert A. Malone took off for the Alaskan tundra to visit one of the hottest of the several hot spots in the global oil company's increasi...
articles.abstract: Last week, just days after he officially took on a new assignment to run BP's business in the United States, Robert A. Malone took off for the Alaskan tundra to visit one of the hottest of the several hot spots in the global oil company's increasingly troubled North American portfolio.     And that's only the beginning of the traveling across the country he will have to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, just days after he officially took on a new assignment to run BP's business in the United States, Robert A. Malone took off for the Alaskan tundra to visit one of the hottest of the several hot spots in the global oil company's increasingly troubled North American portfolio.

articles.headline: 2 Cameras That Break Some Rules
articles.snippet: SO much in technology changes so fast, it's a great mental relief when you encounter an absolute rule that will never change. You know, like ''Whatever you buy today will look overpriced and underpowered next year,'' or ''The next version of Windo...
articles.abstract: SO much in technology changes so fast, it's a great mental relief when you encounter an absolute rule that will never change. You know, like ''Whatever you buy today will look overpriced and underpowered next year,'' or ''The next version of Windows will be bigger than the previous one.''      Two such longstanding rules have just come tumbling down in the world of inexpensive digital S.L.R. (single-lens reflex) cameras. Digital S.L.R.'s are bigger and bulkier than the pocket cameras that most people buy, but they're photographically superior in every regard. They turn on instantly, take stunning magazine-quality photos, have zero shutter lag, can fire three shots a second, offer infinite manual control (white balance, exposure and so on), accept a catalog of lenses and go for days or weeks on a battery charge.
articles.lead_paragraph: SO much in technology changes so fast, it's a great mental relief when you encounter an absolute rule that will never change. You know, like "Whatever you buy today will look overpriced and underpowered next year," or "The next version of Windows will be bigger than the previous one."

articles.headline: White House Prods Congress to Curb Detainee Rights
articles.snippet: A day after saying that terror suspects had a right to protections under the Geneva Conventions, the Bush administration said Wednesday that it wanted Congress to pass legislation that would limit the rights granted to detainees.      The earlier ...
articles.abstract: A day after saying that terror suspects had a right to protections under the Geneva Conventions, the Bush administration said Wednesday that it wanted Congress to pass legislation that would limit the rights granted to detainees.      The earlier statement had been widely interpreted as a retreat, but testimony to Congress by administration lawyers on Wednesday made clear that the picture was more complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 12 - A day after saying that terror suspects had a right to protections under the Geneva Conventions, the Bush administration said Wednesday that it wanted Congress to pass legislation that would limit the rights granted to detainees.

articles.headline: 2 Holdouts Willing To Threaten Tehran
articles.snippet: Russia and China, crossing a diplomatic threshold in the effort to curb Tehran's nuclear ambitions, joined the United States and Europe by agreeing to seek a United Nations Security Council resolution ordering Iran to freeze some nuclear activitie...
articles.abstract: Russia and China, crossing a diplomatic threshold in the effort to curb Tehran's nuclear ambitions, joined the United States and Europe by agreeing to seek a United Nations Security Council resolution ordering Iran to freeze some nuclear activities, or face sanctions.       Article, Page A10.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia and China, crossing a diplomatic threshold in the effort to curb Tehran's nuclear ambitions, joined the United States and Europe by agreeing to seek a United Nations Security Council resolution ordering Iran to freeze some nuclear activities, or face sanctions.
